Most of us in the working and middle classes have had to do quite a bit of mixing by the time we get to college, mainly through YMCA day camps, the Boys and Girls' Club's after-school program, and (oh dear) public schools.

Considering that the wealthy won't need to deal with the hoi polloi beyond their first year or two at college, I wonder whether it's worth it to force them to suffer by being around us? Why do they need to learn empathy for those less fortunate, or be able to navigate social situations with disadvantaged groups?

As long as the kids are well-prepared for the world in which they actually live-- whether or not empathy, sensitivity, or awareness is actually demanded of them--I don't see what difference the roommate makes.
Does obtaining a concealed weapons permit require proof of citizenship?  I don't know, but that's the only question that matters, since that's the ostensible purpose of the statute.
We used to have that requirement to vote as well...it was declared unconstitutional...

You are right that only one course will get you a student ID.  HOWEVER --- at no college can you enter even for one course without paperwork and giving a SS# and a lot of other info.   They don't give out the IDs as if they were dispersing free handwipes, you know.

It's outrageous to allow a weapon permit as ID but not a student ID card. Anyone who thinks that is logical has a serious mental problem... I suspect it's pretty easy to get a gun in Texas, probably a lot easier than getting a student ID card...

Josh,

Reread the concluding sentence in your main comment and think about what it implies. As an intellectual exercise, substitute white for black. Do you now see the enormity of such a sweeping statement?
Do the names Mao and Stalin suggest anything to you?

Yes, it is not just cold, but also logical. Nevertheless, I do not agree with the claim you are making "no atheist ever created such horrors as the inquisition, holy wars, or female genital mutilation, to name just the tip of the iceberg of atrocities based on "God's" dictates.". Just to give one example, in Peru, a terrorist movement called "The Shinning Path" murdered thousands of people. An atrocity headed by an atheist group. Another example, in Mexico, the "War of the Cristeros" represented one of the bloodest times in Mexico, and yes, it was practically started by Plutarco Elías Calles, an atheist.

I can not find a point in that diatribe that you are making. (it do not make your point neither stronger nor weaker). Free thinking is similar to religion: they both should be respected.

From reading this and other things Harris has written, I don't think Harris would disagree with you. I am reasonably certain that he does not believe in "life after death." He is saying that spirituality through mindfulness is a way to better understand and appreciate the consciousness you have while you are alive. He is saying that certain traditions within  Buddhism and Advaita Vedanta shed light on human psychology.

Maybe I just don't get it, but consciousness, self-hood, ceases to exist if there is a short in the brain. Kaput, lights out. All the rest is wishing there is an afterlife to ease the end by those standing by and watching someone ceasing to exist, whether physically or mentally. IMO, it's all science.

This sounds very cold, but that's how I feel; the Jewish belief of living this life to its fullest makes total sense to me (I'm a Jewish atheist). I have a rich, spiritual life directing theater, attending opera and reading great literature. The moment is the important thing, I get through the day perfectly contented; religion is a nice concept if it works for you but no atheist ever created such horrors as the inquisition, holy wars, or female genital mutilation, to name just the tip of the iceberg of atrocities based on "God's" dictates.

Every political hamlet or viceroy wants someone else to pay for their separatism. That state policy does not always reflect the culture or choices citizens would make for their own prosperity. Iceland once had the world's lowest unemployment and, despite high costs, good wages until government policy by elected leaders leveraged its banking debt and the bubble burst--throwing Icelanders out of work (among other things!).

The impact of government policy should include a rigorous review of its best and worst impact on citizens with recommendations for cautions and further study. But mainly policy and studies push single conclusions without a look at the best and worse cases.

Good politics used to mean being versed in both sides of issues and policy. No more! Let's hope the Scots carefully weigh the options on the table, esp, the central and all-important issue of currency and its effects on citizen prosperity.

Slovakia and the Czech Republic had to deal with the same issues when Slovakia became independent in the 1990's, and they actually had little trouble coming to a consensus. And the issues being tackled by Slovakia and by Scotland are minor in comparison to what the new countries that split off from the Soviet Union had to tackle in 1991 and afterward. Yet in most cases (obviously the Ukraine and Georgia being an exception), they managed just fine.

The doom and gloomers on the Scotland issue constantly overstate the difficulties of a post breakup scenario while underestimating people's ability to productively solve those problems. (Also these claims underestimate the tangible damage caused by remaining in a UK that is increasingly ruled by a corrupt, distant government ruled by crony capitalists and special interest money, and with little connection to the people as a whole, especially the Scottish people.) The Scots, in particular, have long shown themselves to be a capable and pragmatic people. They'll do just fine.
Some how wwe need a way to have bi- or non-partisan groups to set up voting districts, but I'm pretty sure that isn't going ot happen anytime soon.

This is a flimsy analysis. Mr. Cohn's argument largely proceeds from an unfounded (and likely unconscious) assumption that there is something approximately "correct" and/or immutable about the current structure of congressional districts. From this unfounded framing assumption -- that we have to deal with more or less the current form of districts even after 2020 -- follows the weak conclusion that only "demographic and generational change" could alter Democratic electoral fortunes in the foreseeable future.

Yes, trends in political self-identification quite obviously favor Republicans with electoral maps that concentrate urban votes into a small number of districts. This is an entirely unremarkable observation. But there's nothing inherently better about this method of map-drawing. There's nothing that forces its retention over drawing more blended districts -- districts that combine urban, suburban, ex-urban, and rural voters in a way that would bring the proportion of seats a party wins much more in line with its actual share of the total vote in a state.

Electoral maps can be drawn quite differently -- starting as soon as the redistricting following the 2020 census. If non-partisan electoral commissions controlled redistricting, we would see more of these districts. And if Democrats had control of the bulk of the state houses in a redistricting year, and an appetite for entrenching themselves in power as the Republicans have done, they could draw even more of them.

Very useful analysis, Dr. Krugman.  If the Scots opt for independence, I hope that they will establish their own central bank and their own currency in due course.  Your analyses since 2008 certainly demonstrate that each nation needs to control its own monetary policy in order to weather economic cycles.
I will believe that Kansas wants to change when it stops being in the bottom half of economic and financial performance in the U.S.
My brother had to wait in line 6 hours to vote for Obama. He lost 6 hours pay.

Don't know why you're so sanguine about the results of vote suppression.  Maybe in a Presidential election year turnout will be good, but in an off year in close races where the district has be gerrymandered and many voters lack citizenship proving documents that can make a real difference to the outcome.

Vote suppression is a rear guard action by the GOP minority who knows they will be swamped eventually by changing demographics.

It is at least heartening that every such GOP action tends to bring out more voters determined not to be suppressed. This motivation gave Florida to Obama in 2012.

Good things happen when people vote.

I live in a sovereign country that is part of another sovereign country. The world is evolving and states need to evolve to support economic, social and political needs. It is quite apparent to me that the greatest threat to the world is that the strongest nation on earth is incapable of evolving to suit its own needs. The fact that the world is rapidly urbanizing and the US is seeing its cities less able to finance their basic needs should point to the need for a new system of governance not envisioned in 1776. Canada is evolving, America not so much.

Outside of a brief nationalistic sense of victory, what real benefit would the people of Scotland have if this Independence goes through? From Catalonia to Corsica it all seems like whimsical nonsense. Are these peoples oppressed? Are they living under dictatorships? Should they break-away all they'll end up with is the same system of government with just a now provincial set of (probably more) corrupt politicians with somewhat appealing accents. And let's not underestimate the blinding ambitions of politicians eager to switch their regional titles to loftier lear-jet having national positions.

If there is structural imbalance, there should be a long-term  right-shift in the curve.  You get worse unemployment for a given vacancy rate.  The Cleveland Fed data suggest there is no permanent, only the commonly seen temporary, right-shift reversed by a more recent left-shift.  Therefore there is no structural barrier to job matching they conclude.  However, the curve also moves left and right depending on changes in the labor force (denominator) not just changes in the number of the employed (nominator).  It would have been better to use U6 not U3 if you want to make a case against structural barriers to unemployment and for continued monetary and fiscal stimulus to decrease cyclical unemployment.  So these data don't mean anything, but they make good fodder for Keynesians.

In a very strong sense, the north American continent was never a "colony" of Great Britain, nor could it have been. England thought we were a colony, but this was implausible, a fantasy. The revolution was merely a means to make them accept the reality. There is really no comparison to Scotland now versus what was becoming America then.

Well, I'm pretty chuffed that you're still here also, though I'm surprised you feel you're against us.

Anyone in particular that you think is odd?

Since many Scottish politicians are left leaning, the Labor party would loose 30 seats and the Tories would win the next election, although Cameron will probably be forced to resign. So, the Scottish referendum, will not only effect Scotland but will have a devastating effect on the left wing of the UK.

If Scotland votes for independence, does that mean that Cameron, with his austerity economic policies, will have 'lost' Scotland? What would be the political and economic repercussions in the UK? Reading the op-ed and the comments, it appears that Scotland might be able to make a go of it if they adopt an independent currency pegged to the pound, and could gain entry to the EU.

"Similarly SH is saying that everyone thinks they exist as a "self" because it is obvious."

He's incorrect if he does -- psychologists noted long ago that the infant must develop a sense of self, and that he initially sees the mother as part of himself.

As to the notion that the self itself is an illusion, that is purely silly. I can look about me and see various selves, and of course there is my own. The supposition that selfhood is not real is patently absurd, and I don't see how it could be arrived at except by someone who had jiggered his *perception* of self and then placed too much faith in his altered perceptions, or through some kind of malfunction such as drug use or psychosis.

So we are back to perception of self.

In his other comments on this issue he does not suggest eliminating it for it's own sake, but because having a deeper understanding of our first person experience can help us achieve different states of experience that we may desire more. For instance, when we are lost in thought bitterly arguing with an image of a friend about something we think they might say — but haven't actually said —, is it better (more conducive to wellbeing) for the totality of our experience (trying to avoid saying the word "us", language is failing me here) if we understand that this is just an object of consciousness not tied to a central thinker?

Part of his argument is that perhaps the way we've experienced things up to now isn't good enough.

Of course, he has a lot of interesting things to say about terms like "better", "wellbeing", etc. that he is using to guide his opinions on this. You'll have to read through all of that to see if you agree. See the Moral Landscape.

Ethan, I'm not sure. I've used the technique of mindful meditation myself with some success, as well as hypnosis. So I'd agree that there's something to be said for these approaches. At the same time, I'm skeptical about claims that the mind is some kind of broken instrument that needs to be fixed. Sometimes, yes, but my overall sense is that we are often meddling in things that we don't understand very well, that some of what we seek to change should not be.

I confess I'm flummoxed by this. The sense of self exists and, if we take a scientific approach we find that it is common to most of the people we observe. and consists of neurons modeling the individual organism -- what we would call the self. It seems silly to blithely wave it away because we can produce states in which we do not perceive it, whether through meditation or pharmaceuticals or simply by going to sleep.

Another way of looking at it is that a computer that was designed to model its own state would have a sense of self, however primitive. Disable the program responsible for monitoring the computer's state, or turn the computer off, and the sense of self would disappear. That makes it no less real.

They will forever face huge obstacles to decent employment, education, travel, housing, government benefits, and will always go into court with one strike against them. They can even have their children taken away!

20 million Americans are now locked away in this very un-American sub-class. That has a horrible effect on the whole country, being an incredible waste of human potential.

The fraudulent prohibition has never accomplished one positive thing. It has only caused vast amounts of crime, corruption, violence, death and the severe diminishment of everyone's freedom.

There is no more important domestic issue than ending what is essentially the American Inquisition.

Just because someone tests positive for MJ doesn't mean they're "impaired" from any recent use of it. MJ stays in a person's system sometimes for months. Do they even test people to see what pharmaceuticals they may be taking? That is the much more likely culprit of any fatal accidents than MJ.

Correlation is not causation.

The claim that stoned driving is safer than drunk driving is beside the point. It’s safer than driving after taking a hit of crack, but driving stoned is driving impaired, and the amount of impairment will vary with age, dose, and a host of other variables. The problem is the potency of mj has steadily increased (with new delivery systems further ramping up the effects). So have documented accidents involving stoned drivers. A study of 3,000 fatalities in Australia showed that a driver was more likely to be at fault when THC was present in the blood of the driver. And the higher the THC, the greater the likelihood of culpability.
There are substantial risks to the heavy user, starting with impaired coordination, rapid pulse, damage to lungs and increases in respiratory illness. I'm not even going to mention adverse fetal effects and loss of IQ points in habitual users. Both physical and psychological addiction occur. Long-term use results in tolerance to THC and withdrawal symptoms when a user tries to stop.
But it’s the liabilities to the innocent bystanders that concern me, the danger to the drivers, passengers, and pedestrians who are at greater risk from stoned drivers. Maybe a little mj makes drivers more cautious, but very stoned drivers can't stay in lanes and don't care. If states are going to legalize (decreasing incarceration costs and increasing incomes via taxes), at least they should set DWI limits low and enforce them. It’s the right thing to do.

When they start driving high, that's when I worry. What we don't need is more folks 'moking doke to join the drunks, prescription druggies, road ragers, texters, and other assorted incompetents out on the road, doin' their thang. Jus' sayin'. Whatever.

I owe much to football, but at 71 as my knees and right shoulder ache more (yeah some nice Indica helps) the amount I owe seems to diminish.  Cannabis never should have been banned.

lol, sounds about right to me!

as a young man i thought i loved football, and in fact i played 3 years in high school, on a top team...but as soon as i started smoking pot in my mid-20s i saw it for what it truly was: tribalistic war for the masses. all the people who feel put-upon in life, and who aren't athletically gifted enough to actually play sports, can bask in the reflected glory of their giant gladiators, and the corporate overlords clean up. imo, football, and mass-market sports in general, are one of the chief ills of modern american society. i look forward to the day when people in the usa say football and mean soccer!

i find it so incomprehensible that any self-respecting potheads would be interested in such a ridiculous and violent sport!  it is basically 4 hours of commercials wrapped in tribalistic war simulations.  blech.  imho, soccer and table tennis are much more in-tune with the universal flow...

As a Japanese tennis fan, I was wondering why there was no Japanese pro-tennis players who reached the final in a big tournament like US open , though we see world-wide successful athletes in other sports events such as golf, baseball, swimming, and figure skating.  The story was quoting the comment of Nishikori's father, saying "Japanese sports programs, with their rigid hierarchies and demands to conform, would not nurture a talent as unique as his son's".   I agree with him and Kei Nishikori would not have succeeded if he had stayed in Japan.  It's sad, but it's true and we must admit it because his talents were developed in the US.  I do hope that Japanese sports programs will be changed to better ones at any levels of education and coaching.

I've lived in japan and there is certainly a reluctance of many Japanese to leave japan for other countries for other than visits--and even then I met a significant number who wouldn't leave even for a short time because of fears for their safety and not being able to get Japanese food. in my experience, many who do leave are considered--or have been for much of their lives--as being un Japanese in many ways. and i'd like to see the gender breakdown--excluding work transfers--for men and women. women, I think, are more likely to leave, more likely to stay abroad and more likely to adjust.

This is an ugly smear with no proof or support. It is also mean spirited and narrow minded. Look at Courtney Paris, Tina Charles, or several of the centers in the WNBA and you will find women athletes with the same physique and build, even larger. The difference? Ms. Williams chose to pursue tennis, one of the difficult and unique routes for minority women athletes rather than more traditional sports. Pushed by an obsessive father, her first coach, her winning has depended on developing a winning attitude and shot making (no drug improves placement, accuracy, or touch!) and good genes and an unusual path to top performance in a sport in which some obviously cannot accept her long success with grace.
